quoteFirst: If only Smith had been shut up next door to me I might have been able to shout to him so that he could hear, but what chance was there when three or four rooms at least divided us?  After all, except that he was near me, and knew where I was, things were not much better than they had been before.  So I sat down again in my corner and sulkily watched the first glimmers of dawn peep in at the little window.  It must be
quoteLast: , I thought.  And that meant four good hours before any chance of a release came.
title: My Friend Smith: A Story of School and City Life
author: Reed, Talbot Baines, 1852-1893

quoteFirst: As there was a porch at the door I decided to sit down there and wait until he did come home. I sat and dozed until
quoteLast: , when I heard some one moving inside the house.
title: The Life of Roger Langdon, Told by himself. With additions by his daughter Ellen.
author: Langdon, Roger, 1825-1894; Langdon, Ellen; Lambert, Henry Clifton [Author of introduction, etc.]

quoteFirst: The expectations of hostile attack were realized in the early hours of February 3, when a force of 12,000 Turks and Germans attacked, and made an attempt to cross the Canal midway between the east bank strong points of Serapeum and Toussoum. Heavy rifle and machine-gun fire developed between those places
quoteLast: The guns of the Egyptian Mountain Battery had, by happy chance or remarkable intuition, been mounted on the west bank within 400 yards of the main crossing-place selected by the Turks. The chanty of the enemy, as, unaware of the battery’s proximity, he attempted to launch the heavy steel pontoons, was much appreciated by the gunners, who opened fire in the dark at point-blank range.
title: The 42nd (East Lancashire) Division 1914-1918
author: Gibbon, Frederick P.

quoteFirst: At one in the morning I was called, and I dressed by the light of a candle. When I got outside I found the men were loading up. We started
quoteLast: His Highness, I found, had gone on. It was excessively dark, and the Armenian and I got off the road and lost our way on the plains. We rode on trusting to our horses, but they were as much at fault as we.
title: At the Court of the Amîr: A Narrative
author: Gray, John Alfred

quoteFirst: McDiarmid, Primrose and myself, besides the officers and crew. We cruised along Moreton Island and caught sufficient fish for our tea, after which we retired to our bunks, and the steamer made for the Tweed Heads.
quoteLast: , we were awakened by the cry of "Fish Oh!" On reaching the deck we found the officers and crew hauling in schnapper as fast as they could bait their hooks. We were all soon engaged in the same sport.
title: Reminiscences of Queensland, 1862-1869
author: Corfield, William Henry, 1843-1927

quoteFirst: At sunset I lighted the fires, and, as soon as steam was up, steered for the passage between Zante and the Morea. The wind freshening much in a contrary direction, I found myself about ten miles to the southward of Zante in the morning.
quoteLast: we perceived a large vessel standing towards us from the Morea, and we went to quarters for her. I thought at first she might be the _Hellas_; but on approaching she stood back to the mainland, which made me conclude that it was a stranger; the wind increasing, I could not remain head to wind, and made sail under the lee of Zante.
title: The Life of Thomas, Lord Cochrane, Tenth Earl of Dundonald, Vol. II
author: Dundonald, Thomas Barnes Cochrane, Earl of, 1814-1885; Bourne, H. R. Fox (Henry Richard Fox), 1837-1909

quoteLast: , December 8, 1908. Along with us came Giglio and another man named Bernardo, a man with a ruddy complexion and a large mouth.
